class.title: 2D Design
class.description: ARTS 1311-2003, Two Dimensional Design, and ARTS 1312-2002, Three Dimensional Design, will be offered in collaboration. Students will work on the elements and principles of design through a coordinated series of assignments which transition from illusionary space to physical space. These linked sections are highly recommended for students majoring in art.
class.alt-description: ARTS 1311-2003, Two Dimensional Design, and ARTS 1312-2002, Three Dimensional Design, will be offered in collaboration. Students will work on the elements and principles of design through a coordinated series of assignments which transition from illusionary space to physical space. These linked sections are highly recommended for students majoring in art.

class.title: 3D Design
class.description: ARTS 1312-2002, Three Dimensional Design, and ARTS 1311-2003, Two Dimensional Design, will be offered in collaboration. These linked sections are highly recommended for students majoring in art.
class.alt-description: ARTS 1312-2002, Three Dimensional Design, and ARTS 1311-2003, Two Dimensional Design, will be offered in collaboration. These linked sections are highly recommended for students majoring in art.

class.description: These hybrid courses have both online and in-class course meetings. The class focus will be on learning to use Adobe Photoshop as an experimental tool for artists. class.title: Business Computer Applications
class.description: BCIS 1405-2421 is online and requires access to the Internet and e-mail along with Microsoft Office 2007, 2003, XP, 2002 or 2000 software, including Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Access. The orientation will be given online, but an optional on-campus orientation will be offered during the first week of class for students who wish help in getting started. For more information call 972-860-4746, e-mail bhcCIT@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege Web site at http://dallastelecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
class.description: Orientation will be Aug. 27 at 7 p.m. in Room K121. An online orientation is also available. Most assignments, tests and quizzes are online. A midterm exam, lab practical 1 & 2 and the final exam will be taken in a DCCCD campus testing center or some other preapproved supervised testing site. Content includes biology in the modern world, DNA, genetics and the cell. For more information contact pShelp@dcccd.edu

class.title: Supervision
class.description: Earn six credit hours, but attend class only three hours one night per week. The program includes personal mentoring from a full-time Management faculty member, small-group interaction and networking with other employed professionals. A student must have current employment in an appropriate job and meet the TSI requirements in reading and writing. It is a requirement that any student taking a management Co-op course at Brookhaven College for the first time, must call the instructor for permission before registering in these courses. Call Marisa Walsdorf 972-860-4186, marisa_walsdorf@dcccd.edu or www.brookhavencollege.edu/management.

class.title: Coop. Ed. Bus. Admin. and Mgt.
class.description: Earn six credit hours, but attend class only three hours one night per week. The program includes personal mentoring from a full-time Management faculty member, small-group interaction and networking with other employed professionals. A student must have current employment in an appropriate job and meet the TSI requirements in reading and writing. It is a requirement that any student taking a management Co-op course at Brookhaven College for the first time, must call the instructor for permission before registering in these courses. Call Marisa Walsdorf 972-860-4186, marisa_walsdorf@dcccd.edu or www.brookhavencollege.edu/management.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: CUST 2370, section 2001, Mexico: A Cultural Perspective. This theme-driven, multicultural, interdisciplinary course will study the historical, political, social, religious, artistic and business traditions of Mexico. Students must have Internet access and a current e-mail address. Students may obtain a free e-mail account by logging onto www.BrookhavenCollege.edu, then click on "N" for NetMail.
class.alt-description: CUST 2370, section 2001, Mexico: A Cultural Perspective. This theme-driven, multicultural, interdisciplinary course will study the historical, political, social, religious, artistic and business traditions of Mexico. Students must have Internet access and a current e-mail address. Students may obtain a free e-mail account by logging onto www.BrookhavenCollege.edu, then click on "N" for NetMail.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: This course focuses on topics related to Caribbean culture and arts, with special emphasis on the impact of the African influence within the broader Caribbean, Central, and South American regions.
class.alt-description: This course focuses on topics related to Caribbean culture and arts, with special emphasis on the impact of the African influence within the broader Caribbean, Central, and South American regions.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: The topic of this course is collecting and connoisseurship. Students will be taught how to analyze collectibles, antiques and art in order to determine value and origin.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: Selected topics in World Cultures: Students will develop cultural analysis skills by examining African, African American, Native American, Asian, and Hispanic cultures. A comparative exploration and their relationships to each other and to Western societies will be discussed.

class.description: DRAM 1221.2735 is the first play of the fall semester. Auditions: Sept. 9, 10 and 11 at 7 p.m. in the Performance Hall. Performances: Oct. 16-18, 23-25 at 8 p.m. and Oct. 19 and 26 at 2:30 p.m. Please call Jane Quetin for more information at 972-860-4742 or 214-957-6428.

class.title: Theater Practicum II
class.description: DRAM 1221.2736 is the second play of the fall semester. Auditions: Oct. 20 and 22 at 7 p.m., and Oct. 25 at 1 p.m. in the Arena Theater, Room C205. class.title: World Lit
class.description: This course examines the trials and tribulations faced by the hero on his journey toward enlightenment. Through this exploration, students will examine the meaning in their own journeys in order to gain a greater insight into their purposes in life.

class.title: GAME Creation & Design
class.description: GAME 1406-2501 covers basic game theory, design, and concepts and will work in conjunction with GAME 1409 to design and create gaming and simulation projects. Open source software and tools will be used.
class.alt-description: GAME 1406-2501 covers basic game theory, design, and concepts and will work in conjunction with GAME 1409 to design and create gaming and simulation projects. Open source software and tools will be used.

class.title: Animation Programming
class.description: GAME 1409-2501 covers animation programming and development focusing on key-frame and skeletal animation for gaming, simulation and virtual environments. Open source software and tools will be used.
class.alt-description: GAME 1409-2501 covers animation programming and development focusing on key-frame and skeletal animation for gaming, simulation and virtual environments. Open source software and tools will be used.

class.title: GAME Prog 1 - C++
class.description: GAME 1443-2502 is a basic introduction to the C++ programming language and game programming including basic modeling, game physics, game mathematics and personal computer hardware capabilities.
class.alt-description: GAME 1443-2502 is a basic introduction to the C++ programming language and game programming including basic modeling, game physics, game mathematics and personal computer hardware capabilities.

class.title: Learning Framework
class.description: New workbooks for HDEV 1300 are required. HDEV 1300 will help students to develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, understanding the psychology of the classroom, reading/writing techniques, note- and test taking techniques, and the development of critical thinking skills.
class.alt-description: New workbooks are required.

class.title: Learning Framework
class.description: Students who register for HDEV 1300-2002 must also register for DMAT 0066-2001. New workbooks for HDEV 1300 are required. HDEV 1300 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, understanding the psychology of the classroom, note- and test taking skills, reading/writing, techniques, and developing critical thinking.

Online submission is optional.

class.title: Asp.Net Web Programming
class.description: INEW 1440-2426 covers Web programming with databases using Microsoft Visual Studio with Visual Basic or C# and Access and SQL Server databases. Students who take this course should already be familiar with basic HTML and basic programming in VB or C# (ITSC 2435, ITSE 1432, BCIS 1431, ITSE 1430 or equivalent experience). It is online and requires access to the Internet and e-mail. The orientation will be given online. For more information call 972-860-4329, e-mail bhcCITWeb@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege Web site at http://dallastelecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Legacy Family Tree, Part III
class.description: Legacy Family Tree Part III will cover how to use the U.S. County Verifier and the GeoDatabase to correct locations. In this four-session course, students will also learn how to use the Picture Center to manage pictures and print them in reports and how to prepare ToDo and Chronology reports to aid in your research. Prerequisite: Legacy Family Tree, Part I.
class.alt-description: Legacy Family Tree Part III will cover how to use the U.S. County Verifier and the GeoDatabase to correct locations. In this four-session course, students will also learn how to use the Picture Center to manage pictures and print them in reports and how to prepare ToDo and Chronology reports to aid in yoru research. Prerequisite: Legacy Family Tree, Part I.

class.title: Legacy Family Tree Part IV
class.description: Legacy Family Tree IV students will bring their Family File to class and enter individuals, events and sources during the class. Tips, tricks and techniques using events, source citations, locations, complex searches and customized reports will be discussed in this four-session course. Recommended Prerequisite: Legacy Family Tree Part I.
class.alt-description: Legacy Family Tree IV students will bring their Family File to class to enter individuals, events and sources during the class. Tips, tricks and techniques using events, source citations, locations, complex searches and customized reports will be discussed in this four-session course. Recommended Prerequisite: Legacy Family Tree Part I.

class.title: Tracing Your Family Tree Parti
class.description: Tracing Your Family Tree I will enable students to discover their ancestral past through a classroom genealogical journey. Using Hands-on computerized searches and in-class discussion, this four-session course will introduce the family historian to the concepts, methods, sources and resources used in successful genealogical research.
class.alt-description: Tracing Your Family Tree I will enable students to discover their ancestral past through a classroom genealogical journey. Using hands-on computerized searches and in-class discussion, this four session course will introduce the family historian to the concepts, methods sources and resources used in successful genealogical research.

class.title: Tracing Your Family Tree Part
class.description: Tracing Your Family Tree II will continue your fascinating genealogical journey of ancestral discovery. In this four-session course, the instructor will guide students deeper into the labyrinth of traditional historical and genealogical records sources, research methods, Internet web sites and search engines.
class.alt-description: Tracing Your Family Tree II will continue your fascinating genealogical journey of ancestral discovery. In this four-session course, the instructor will guide students deeper into the labyrinth of traditional historical and genealogical records sources, research methods, Internet web sites and search engines.

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: Digital Camersas will cover the various features of a digital camera. In course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in emails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.
class.alt-description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. In course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in emails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.

Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.

class.title: Photoshop Elements Part 1
class.description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements Part I
class.description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements Part II
class.description: Photoshop Elements Part II will build on skills from Elements Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as dust and spot removal. In this six-session course you will also use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements Part II will build on skills from Elements Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as dust and spot removal. In this six-session course you will also use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements Part III
class.description: Photoshop Elements Part III will build on skills from Elements Part II. Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of phots and how to work with various types of layers, including text layers. In this six-session course, you will also experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Required Prerequisite:Photoshop Elements II.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements Part III will build on skills from Elements Part II. Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of phots and how to work with various types of layers, including text layers. In this six-session course, you will also experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Required Prerequisite:Photoshop Elements II.

class.title: Photo Restoration
class.description: Photo Restoration will help you preserve memories of the past. In this six-session course, students will learn to scan, rebuild, repair and salvage your vintage and other damaged photos using Photoshop Elements. Preserve and protect those memories for the future by archiving them in a digital format.
class.alt-description: Photo Restoration will help you preserve memories of the past. In this six-session course, students will learn to scan, rebuild, repair and salvage your vintage and other damaged photos using Photoshop Elements. Preserve and protect those memories for the future by archiving them in a digital format.

class.title: Photo Collage
class.description: Collage with Photoshop Elements is a six-session course that will enable students to learn how to create collages by arranging and blending together digital images, drawings, text, and scanned images to create and artistic composition for a variety of collage projects. Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I.
class.alt-description: Collage with Photoshop Elements is a six-session course that will enable students to learn how to create collages by arranging and blending together digital images, drawings, text, and scanned images to create and artistic composition for a variety of collage projects. Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I.

class.title: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills
class.description: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this course you will practice using the mouse, learn about the componenets of the computer, including the keyboard, and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing the Basic Computer you will be ready to enroll in Intro. to Computers/Windows XP.
class.alt-description: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this course you will practice using the mouse, learn about the componenets of the computer, including the keyboard, and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing the Basic Computer you will be ready to enroll in Intro. to Computers/Windows XP.

class.title: Vista for Xp Users
class.description: Vista for XP Users will cover the difference in Windows XP and Windows Vista and some of the pitfalls/problems between the two operating systems. In this six-session course, students will also learn how to determine if a program that ran on XP has been tested or not tested to run on Vista.
class.alt-description: Vista for XP Users will cover the difference in Windows XP and Windows Vista and some of the pitfalls/problems between the two operating systems. In this six-session course, students will also learn how to determine if a program that ran on XP has been tested or not tested to run on Vista.

class.description: Vista for XP Users will cover the difference in Windows XP and Windows Vista and some of the pitfalls/problems between the two operating systems. class.title: Buying/Selling/Internet
class.description: Buying/Selling on the Internet is a six-session course that will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. Students will learn how to write an effective ad and format ad photos and become acquainted with feedback and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Beginning Internet.
class.alt-description: Buying/Selling on the Internet is a six-session course that will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. Students will learn how to write an effective ad and format ad photos and become acquainted with feedback and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Beginning Internet.

class.title: Data Security
class.description: Data Security teaches you how to protect your personal computer and the information stored in it. In this six-session course, students learn to take care of their personal identity information, how to avoid premature computer hardware failures, how to safely surf the web, manage passwords, PINs, and account numbers. Guarding against attacks from the internet and malicious e-mail attachments are also covered. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.
class.alt-description: Data Security teaches you how to protect your personal computer and the information stored in it. In this six-session course, students learn to take care of their personal identity information, how to avoid premature computer hardware failures, how to safely surf the web, manage passwords, PINs, and account numbers. Guarding against attacks from the internet and malicious e-mail attachments are also covered. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Excel 2003/Part I
class.description: Excell 2003, Part I will develop skills in the basics of Microsoft Excel, a program for spreadsheet and arithmetic functions. This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving, and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, shortcuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.
class.alt-description: Excell 2003, Part I will develop skills in the basics of Microsoft Excel, a program for spreadsheet and arithmetic functions. This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving, and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, shortcuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Excel 2007/Part I
class.description: Excell 2007, Part I will develop skills in the basics of Microsoft Excel, a program for spreadsheet and arithmetic functions. This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving, and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, shortcuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving, and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, shortcuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Internet I
class.description: Internet Part I will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. This six-session course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other Search Engines, addressing Web pages, using Instant Messenger and Discussion Groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.
class.alt-description: Internet Part I will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL, and other browsers. This six session course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other Search Engines, addressing Web pages, using Instant Messenger and Discussion Groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Internet II
class.description: Internet Part II will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies, and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows and Internet/Part I.
class.alt-description: Internet Part II will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies, and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows and Internet/Part I.

class.title: Publisher
class.description: Publisher will introduce the design of a variety of publications, such as greeting cards, invitations, fliers, newsletters, postcards, calendars, business cards and signs. This six-session course will also cover predefined layouts that may be used to simplify formatting your publication if you do not design your own layout.
class.alt-description: Publisher will introduce the design of a variety of publications, such as greeting cards, invitations, fliers, newsletters, postcards, calendars, business cards and signs. This six-session course will also cover predefined layouts that may be used to simplify formatting your publication if you do not design your own layout.

class.title: Software Survey 2007
class.description: Software Survey 2007 will introduce Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Access and other software packages. In this six-session course, students will complete short exercises to become acquainted with the various 2007 software programs.
class.alt-description: Software Survey 2007 will introduce Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Access and other software packages. In this six-session course, students will complete short exercises to become acquainted with the various 2007 software programs.

class.title: Tips and Tricks/Windows XP
class.description: Tips and Tricks/Windows XP will deal with improving Windows XP computer performance and fixing problems. In this six-session course, students learn easy ways to find what they want, customize and organize their files and photos, eliminate clutter and increase speed of operations. The session on Web browsing includes organizing and managing favorites, cookies, browser history and connection problems. Tips on avoiding and managing spam e-mail and organization will also be covered. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows.

The session on Web browsing includes organizing and managing favorites, cookies, browser history and connection problems. Tips on avoiding and managing spam e-mail and organization will also be covered. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Users Group/Problem Solving
class.description: Users Group & Problem Solving meets four times during the semester. Each session has a theme/topic and provides demonstrations to increase student knowledge of computers, software and the internet. In addition, students will have the opportunity to ask questions about their own computers and the software problems they are encountering. The course meets on Fridays, September 5, October 3, November 7 and December 5.
class.alt-description: Users Group & Problem Solving meets four times during the semester. Each session has a theme/topic and provides demonstrations to increase student knowledge of computers, software and the internet. In addition, students will have the opportunity to ask questions about their own computers and the software problems they are encountering. The course meets on Fridays, September 5, October 3, November 7 and December 5.

class.title: Word 2007/Part I
class.description: Word 2007 Part I will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. This six-session course includes creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts; formatting, cutting, copying and pasting text; margins and indents; and inserting graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows.
class.alt-description: Word 2007 Part I will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. This six-session course includes creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts; formatting, cutting, copying and pasting text; margins and indents; and inserting graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows.

class.title: Tips and Tricks/Vista
class.description: Tips and Tricks/Vista is a six-session course that will cover how to navigate and customize the start menus and desktop, as well as configuring the sidebar. Other areas that will be covered are Explorer 7, Media Center improvements, Movie Maker and DVD Maker, Vista's security features and new search features. Recommended prerequisite: Intro to Windows Vista.
class.alt-description: Tips and Tricks/Vista is a six-session course that will cover how to navigate and customize the start menus and desktop, as well as configuring the sidebar. Other areas that will be covered are Explorer 7, Media Center improvements, Movie Maker and DVD Maker, Vista's security features and new search features. Recommended prerequisite: Intro to Windows Vista.

class.description: ITSC 1191 covers touch typing including the alphabet, number and symbol keys. Textbook with specialized software is required.

class.title: Internet Part I
class.description: Internet Part I will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. This six-session course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other Search Engines, addressing Web pages, using Instant Messenger and Discussion Groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.
class.alt-description: Internet Part I will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. This six-session course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other Search Engines, addressing Web pages, using Instant Messenger and Discussion Groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows.

class.title: Internet II
class.description: Internet Part II will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies, and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows and Internet/Part I.
class.alt-description: Internet Part II will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies, and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro. to Windows and Internet/Part I.

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. In course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in emails, and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.
class.alt-description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. In course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in emails, and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.

class.title: Photoshop Elements Part 1
class.description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements Part I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this course, you will also develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening, and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet Part I.

class.title: Web Page I
class.description: Web Page Design Part I will focus on designing a simple personal or business Web site and covers how to put photos online and create e-mail links. In this five session course, students will learn about free or inexpensive Web site hosting for their personal site. No prior knowledge of web design is required. Students must be able to attend all classes. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows & Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Web Page Design Part I will focus on designing a simple personal or business Web site and covers how to put photos online and create e-mail links. Students must be able to attend all classes. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows & Internet, Part I.

class.title: Web Page II
class.description: Web Page Design Part II will build upon the skills of Web Page I by adding to your web site. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro. to Windows & Internet Part I.

class.title: Medical Terminology
class.description: This course meets eight weeks. Medical Terminology requires a computer with access to the Internet and e-mail along with Microsoft 2003 or 2007 software. This course is designed as a hybrid course that includes online instruction, online chapter quizzes and two on-campus exams. Course content is delivered online in PowerPoint presentations, threaded discussions, and textbook interactive activities along with self assessments found on student's CD included with textbook. NOTE: This course is required prior to taking Med. Coding Basics and Med. Ins. Online orientation. For more information, call 972-860-4174, e-mail bhcBOSS@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege Web site at http://dallastelecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Music Appreciation
class.description: This four-weekend course is designed to impart an understanding of classical music as an element of contemporary culture and to develop the power of listening intelligently. Masterworks in music literature will be explored through attending live performances. No technical knowledge is required. An additional fee of $100 for Dallas Symphony Orchestra tickets must be paid by October 17, 2008. For more information, contact Ricky Reeves at 972-860-4676.
class.alt-description: This four-weekend course is designed to impart an understanding of classical music as an element of contemporary culture and to develop the power of listening intelligently. Masterworks in music literature will be explored through attending live performances. No technical knowledge is required. An additional fee of $100 for Dallas Symphony Orchestra tickets must be paid by October 17, 2008. For more information, contact Ricky Reeves at 972-860-4676.

class.title: Music Literature
class.description: For more information, please call Octavio Gutierrez at 972-860-4720. Orientation is Aug. 27 at noon in Room D207. If the institution to which the student wishes to transfer requires only one music literature course, the students should take MUSI 1308. If it requires two literature courses, the student should take MUSI 1308 and MUSI 1309. These courses are taught in English with a bilingual instructor.

class.title: Prin of Nutrit
class.description: This course is an introduction to human nutrition. In addition to learning how the body handles nutrients, students analyze personal eating habits; develop a personal weight control plan; analyze food labels; distinguish between nutrition fact and myth; identify relationships between nutrition and disease; and integrate nutrition information into daily lives. All sections have an Internet component; students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.
class.alt-description: This course is an introduction to human nutrition. In addition to learning how the body handles nutrients, students analyze personal eating habits; develop a personal weight control plan; analyze food labels; distinguish between nutrition fact and myth; identify relationships between nutrition and disease; and integrate nutrition information into daily lives. All sections have an Internet component; students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.

class.title: Beginning Tai Chi Chuan
class.description: This course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form characterized by low, non-impact movements designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.
class.alt-description: This course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form characterized by low, non-impact movements designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.

class.title: Beginning Yoga/Pilates.
class.description: This combination course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact aerobic warmups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.description: This beginning overall fitness course is designed for students 50 years and older. It includes cardiovascular walking and rhythmic activities; weight training using small free weights and tubing; and flexibility training. Accommodation is made for different levels of fitness.

class.title: Inter. Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: This intermediate overall fitness course is designed for students 50 years and older. It includes cardiovascular walking and rhythmic activities; weight training using small free weights and tubing; and flexibility training. Accommodation will be made for different levels of fitness.
class.alt-description: This intermediate overall fitness course is designed for students 50 years and older. It includes cardiovascular walking and rhythmic activities; weight training using small free weights and tubing; and flexibility training. Accommodation is made for different levels of fitness.

class.title: Inter Yoga/Pilates
class.description: This combination course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact aerobic warmups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.
class.alt-description: This combination course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact impact aerobic warmups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.title: Inter. Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: This Tai Chi Chuan course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form presented beyond the beginner level. It is designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.
class.alt-description: This Tai Chi Chuan course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form presented beyond the beginner level. It is designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.

Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.title: Inter Self Def
class.description: This course utilizes both Northern and Southern styles of the Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach advanced self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.

class.title: Hlth for Today
class.description: This course is restricted to ECHS students. Emphasis is placed on relating course content to lifestyle for a better understanding of major health issues of today. Issues include but are not limited to emotional health, chemical use and abuse, human sexuality, major diseases, physical fitness, nutrition, aging, death and dying. This course does not satisfy the physical education activity course requirement.

class.title: Gen Physics
class.description: PHYS 1401 is an algebra/trigonometry-based physics course for pre-dental, pre-pharmacy and pre-architecture majors and other students who need a two-semester technical course in physics. It is recommended that students take MATH 1414 (College Algebra) and MATH 1316 (Trigonometry) prior to taking PHYS 1401.

class.alt-description: PHYS 1411 is a four-hour lab science course for non-science majors. Students are required to attend some Wednesday evening observing sessions. Schedule will be announced in lab.

class.title: Fund Astronomy
class.description: Orientation for PHYS 1411-2426 online course will be Aug. 27, 6-7 p.m. in Room K251. Students are required to have a personal computer with access to the Internet and e-mail. Lectures, labs and tests are online. Some outdoor observations are required. PHYS 1411 is a Core Curriculum course for non-science majors and includes the study of planetary astronomy.

class.title: Intro. to Comp/Windows XP
class.description: Introduction to Computers and Windows XP is a beginning computer course that focuses on the terminology of the Microsoft Windows XP operating system. Components of personal computers, hardware and software will be taught as well as menu bars, toolbars and shortcuts. You will learn to name, save, locate and print files and also use the word processing program to create, edit and format files.

class.title: Medical Coding Basics
class.description: Prerequisite required: MDCA 1213 Medical Terminology or an equivalent medical terminology course. Course requires a computer with access to the Internet and e-mail. This course is designed as a hybrid course, which means the orientation and course content are delivered on campus using lecture, demonstrations and group activities. In addition to the on campus activities, quizzes, tests and interactive lab activities are posted online. For more information, call Sharon Burton at 972-860-4163 or Pat Byars at 972-860-4170.

course.title: Spc Tpcs in Spanish Lang/Liter
course.long-title: Special Topics in Spanish Language and Literature

class.title: Beginning Spanish Language
class.description: Beginning Spanish is a ten-week course to build beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
class.alt-description: Beginning Spanish is a ten-week course to build beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.

class.title: Intermediate Spanish
class.description: Intermediate Spanish is a continuation of Beginning Spanish and seeks to develop additional vocabulary and speaking skills. In this ten-week course you will continue oral practice, as well as the reading, writing, and grammar skills necessary to enhance your communication and comprehension skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended Prerequisite: Beginning Spanish or permission of instructor.
class.alt-description: Intermediate Spanish is a continuation of Beginning Spanish and seeks to develop additional vocabulary and speaking skills. In this ten-week course you will continue oral practice, as well as the reading, writing, and grammar skills necessary to enhance your communication and comprehension skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended Prerequisite: Beginning Spanish or permission of instructor.

class.title: Special Topics in Spanish
class.description: Special Topics is a ten-week course that will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended prerequisite: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor.
class.alt-description: Special Topics is a ten-week course that will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended prerequisite: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor.
